sub_title: Professor clinical physics radiotherapy, University of Amsterdam at Amsterdam UMC
summary: Background in both physics and software engineering. Keywords: image guided/adaptive radiotherapy and hyperthermia.

projects.title: 3D dose reconstruction for children with long-term follow-up Toward improved decision making in radiation treatment for children with cancer
projects.description: We will develop and validate a novel approach to reconstruct 3D dose distributions of historically-treated patients for whom RT planning CT scans are not available. We will develop state-of-the art learning and optimization algorithms from computer science to match each historically-treated patient with recently-treated patients for whom 3D CT scans are available, followed by geometrical and dosimetric reconstructions.

projects.title: Addition of brachytherapy and external beam dose for cervical cancer
projects.description: In this project we develop methods for a  biological summation of dose delivered with two modalities (brachytherapy and external beam radiotherapy). Challenges include organ deformation and adequate values for the biological parameters.

contributors.headline: Professor clinical physics radiotherapy, University of Amsterdam at Amsterdam UMC
Principal Investigator (Associate Professor), Radiation Oncologist at Amsterdam UMC

projects.title: Dose-guided adaptive radiotherapy for pancreas cancer, using Cone Beam CT
projects.description:
Pancreatic cancer still has a very poor prognosis.The challenge for irradiation is to deal with the mobile anatomy. Our techniques include enhanced visualisation of the pancreas with gold markers, breath control and adaptive dose guided procedures. By improving the irradiation we will reduce side effects and enable future dose-escalation.
Sponsor: KWF (with special thanks to "Stichting Bergh in het zadel", www.berginhetzadel.nl).

projects.title: Adaptive radiotherapy for cervix tumors
projects.description:
There are two major challenges in this project (1) location of the tumor (2) geometrical uncertainty during irradiation. For (1) we will correlate imaging (MRI/CT) with pathological data, and for (2) we aim at using Cone Beam CT data during treatment, using newly developed deformation methods.
Sponsor: AMC internal

Radiation Oncologist at Radiotherapeutisch Instituut Friesland

projects.title: Child-tailored image guided adaptive radiotherapy: because children are not adults.
projects.description:
BACKGROUND
Children with cancer have a higher risk than adults to develop severe radiation-associated adverse effects, such as delay in growth and the risk of secondary cancers. Reducing such risks is therefore  pertinent for children.
Due to their smaller proportions, small organ motion or small anatomical changes will have a larger impact than in adults. The project focuses on organ motion in children treated for abdominal and/or thoracic tumors using image-guided (adaptive) radiotherapy (IG(A)RT). To deal with organ motion, a safety-margin is defined around the tumor, ensuring sufficient tumor dose delivery. The optimal extent of this margin is of the utmost importance: a too small margin results in underdosage of the tumor, a too large margin yields unnecessary radiation damage of healthy tissue. However, for children the optimal margin extent is unknown since quantitative studies of organ motion in children are extremely scarce.

AIM
Reduction of the risk of radiation toxicity in children by quantifying organ motion, enabling child-tailored radiotherapy procedures and bringing IG(A)RT in pediatric oncology at least to the level of that in adults.

PLAN OF INVESTIGATION
1: Analyze organ motion during radiotherapy, including imaging data of an international collaborative network (≥ 172 patients).
2: A survey using the Delphi method regarding the status of IG(A)RT. Opinions of experts will be collected. The experts’ opinions should converge on the best IG(A)RT practice, yielding recommendations.
3: The potential benefit of probabilistic adaptive treatment techniques will be explored.

EXPECTED OUTCOME 
We will take the urgently needed step forwards in the quality of pediatric radiotherapy, yielding recommendations of the best practices. We will yield a future reduction of adverse effects of children undergoing radiotherapy.
Sponsor: KWF

projects.title: Radiotherapy and hyperthermia for children: from concept to breakthrough?
projects.description:
Hyperthermia is a non-toxic treatment whereby the tumor and surrounding area is heated locally to enhance the effect of radiotherapy. High-quality hyperthermia results in damage to tumor only, leaving the normal healthy tissue unaffected. For adults, hyperthermia is a standard treatment for several tumors but for children it is very rarely applied and in the Netherlands not at all.
In this project we will investigate the potential added value of hyperthermia for children with computer models for several cancer types (Wilms' tumors, neuroblastomas and sarcomas). We will use existing (imaging) data of previously treated patients to simulate the treatment. In this way we will get a quantitative indication of the technical feasibility and the potential clinical gain of hyperthermia for children. When this proves to be feasible and beneficial, this project will be the starting point for the  future introduction of hyperthermia for children in the Netherlands.
Sponsor: KiKa

projects.title: Towards biological treatment planning in radiotherapy combined with hyperthermia to improve clinical outcome
projects.description:
Two major topics are studied:
1. An adequate way to describe the effect of hyperthermia as a supplemental dose in radiotherapy. This is basically a mathematical and software challenge.
2. A quantification of the biological parameters that determine the advantageous effect of hyperthermia. This biological oriented part of the project is carried out in close collaboration with the AMC-based biological lab LEXOR, where in-vivo and in-vitro experiments are carried out.

projects.title: Adaptive treatment planning techniques using external beam irradiation
projects.description:
For a range of mobile organs/targets we want to develop adaptive treatment planning procedures to enhance dose delivery. The expertise acquired during this project will be used to enhance support for adaptive procedures in the treatment planning system (Oncentra). 
Sponsor: Nucletron B.V.

Integrations Engineer bij Channable
Research Scientist at Akademiska sjukhuset
Klinisch fysicus bij Amsterdam UMC

projects.title: Organ motion during high-precision radiation therapy: why treat children like adults?
projects.description:
In image-guided radiotherapy accurate knowledge of organ motion is of the utmost importance. Especially for children, an inadequate margin definition can result in severe consequences: a decreased local control caused by a geographic miss of the tumor or an increased risk of late effects from unnecessary radiation to healthy tissues. 
Organ motion in adults has been widely analyzed, but quantitative data for children is extremely sparse. Therefore, the aim of this project is to quantify organ motion in children during radiotherapy. In the first stage of this pilot project we focus on mobility (inter- and intrafraction) of organs in the abdominal and thoracic region.
Sponsor: KIKA.

projects.title: Evaluation of stepping source brachytherapy treatment plans obtained by the novel interactive optimization methods EGO and IIP, with a restricted set of DVH parameters.
projects.description:
In this project we aim at making criteria for a 'good brachyplan' objective. These criteria are included in the treatment planning software.
Sponsors: Nucletron/Elekta and AMC/internal.

projects.title: Deformable matching techniques
projects.description:
Deformable matching techniques are a prerequisite for effective dose accumulation during radiotherapy ("which part of an organ gets how much dose"). In this project we develop methods for adequate deformable matching techniques special interest for the anatomical accuracy.
Sponsor: General Electric

projects.title: MRI techniques for pancreatic cancer
projects.description:
In this project we aim at developing advanced MRI techniques for improved visualisation of the pancreas and pancreatic cancer.
Sponsors: shared between AMC Radiotherapy (partly covered by KWF) and AMC Radiology.

contributors.headline: Professor clinical physics radiotherapy, University of Amsterdam at Amsterdam UMC

projects.title: High precision image guided radiotherapy for bladder cancer
projects.description:
In this project we develop novel techniques for better irradiation of the bladder. Improvements include improved tumor visibility during treatment by lipidiol injections around the tumour and deformation and automated detection of the bladder on Cone Beam CT. The project is a collaboration with the Netherlands Cancer Institute. 
Sponsor: Dutch Cancer Society (KWF).

contributors.headline: Professor clinical physics radiotherapy, University of Amsterdam at Amsterdam UMC
CEO at Huiying (Beijing) tecnology inc

projects.title: Advanced imaged guided treatment planning techniques for mobile tumors
projects.description:
The treatment planning techniques for mobile targets (bladder, lung) was improved, using advanced techniques previously not yet applied for these tumor sites. Research also included the potential dosimetric effects of daily patient setup correction (i.e. shift invariance of the dose) for lung and bladder.
Sponsor: Nucletron B.V.

projects.title: Improvement of geometrical treatment accuracy and dose delivery for bladder cancer using implanted clips
projects.description:
This project focused on the planning requirements for adaptive techniques: fast/real time dose calculation (using GPU) and automatic organ segmentation.
Sponsors: Stichting Odas and Nucletron B.V.

profile_positions.title: Professor clinical physics radiotherapy, University of Amsterdam
Head of radiotherapy physics (locations VUmc and AMC)

profile_positions.description: Management of physics/technical group at the AMC radiotherapy department. Clinical and research topics include hyperthermia, image guided radiotherapy and treatment planning.
profile_positions.title: Head of Radiotherapy Physics

profile_positions.description: Development of treatment planning software, interaction between users (hospitals/radiotherapy departments) and R&D.
profile_positions.title: Physicist/software engineer

profile_positions.description: All aspects of clinical physics in radiotherapy (hands-on tasks in quality assurance of linacs, daily patient treatments). Development and maintenance of open-source treatment planning system (GRATIS). Research in various areas (treatment planning, patient position verification).

profile_positions.description: Research on patient position verification with electronic portal imaging and consequences of positional uncertainties for delivered dose (safety margins).
